title: Director of Strategic Information Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Partners in Health in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted about an interview, never sent an invite, had to ask if the interview was still on, and then I had the interview. The HR person never said that it was a panel interview, started 15mins late, and never introduced who I was talking to. The interview was extremely rushed. They started late, left no time for questions, I had to ask who I was interviewing with, and the questions left no time for me to explain anything. title: Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Partners in Health
Interview Descriptions: Long and drawn out interview process was somewhat a waste of time and effort, more than four months from application submission to assuming that the org had decided not to hire (never heard back). After this long process radio silence, even after polite follow up emails, which seems to be a red flag. After investing the time to make the candidate jump through so many hoops, why would you ignore the candidate who simply wants a yes/no?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Partners in Health (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions:
Worked with an external recruiter. The process took 4+ months. PIH is very disjointed, disorganized, and frankly, rude to candidates. I had interviews rescheduled several times at the last minute...like within 5 minutes of a call. When there was a confirmed call or face-to-face meeting, the PIH representative was 20-40 minutes late. The standard apology was that they were in another meeting with important and interesting people.

Given the work that PIH does, the level of dismissive elitism, coupled with the obvious white-only leadership, is disheartening and bodes poorly for the future of this organization.
Interview Questions: Why should we hire you?

title: Operations and Planning Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Partners in Health in Jul 2016
Interview Descriptions: PIH reached out to me within a week of submitting the application. I had one interview with an HR representative and another with the director of the program. Both interviewers were pleasant and professional. However, after the second interview, the director informed me that I made it to a third round of interviews and that I would be contacted within a week by the program manager. The program manager never reached out and, despite two follow up emails, I never heard back from the organization.
Interview Questions: Describe your budgeting experience. How many times have you construct a program budget?

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Partners in Health in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions: I applied online for a position at a field site and had an initial phone interview with someone from HR in Boston. She didn't seem to know much about the position, and wasn't able to answer some fairly basic questions, which made it sound like the details hadn't really been hammered out and/or she wasn't super aware of what was going on in the field. I was told I would hear back within two weeks; I never heard anything. Not cool. But what really gave me a bad impression was that, while I was applying for the job, I reached out to several people who I had worked with a few summers back while an intern at PIH. I found out that ALL of the 5-6 people on the team that I had interned on just 2 years ago had since left the organization. HUGE red flag. Even though my internship experience at PIH was super positive, I don't think I'll be applying to any jobs here ever again.

title: Chief Financial Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Partners in Health (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Prolonged and arduous
Interview Questions: Political inclination.

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Partners in Health (Boston, MA) in Aug 2013
Interview Descriptions: I applied for a director-level position and interviewed with senior level staff.  I had two phone calls (one with the recruiter and the other with the hiring manager) and came to the office on two separate occasions to meet with a series of people. I sent thank you emails to every person, and patiently waited for a follow up.  After over a month of no contact, I asked for an update. Two weeks later I received an email from the recruiter saying they were having a hard time getting everyone's calendars in order to finalize the process.  That was the last contact with anyone one.  I never received *any* follow up with anyone to let me know if the position had been filled or that I was no longer being considered.  I even followed up twice with the recruiter.  Why is it that it is acceptable for organizations to not have the decency to get back to you after an interview?
Interview Questions: A mix of pre-determined behavior questions and general conversation

title: Director of Corporate and Foundation Relations Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Partners in Health
Interview Descriptions:
I have never been through such a long and disorganized interviewing  process, with little regard for the prospective employee. I first spoke on the phone with an HR manager, then with a VP who did not seem to know much about my area of work. Then I met with the CFO who made me come at 8:30am but showed up at 9:00 am (I was standing in the street until he came). He did not seem to know what to ask me. Then I was asked to meet with 8 other people. I was never told by anyone that one of the persons I met with was actually the acting director for the position I was interviewed for. There were weeks of waiting in between these interviewing episodes with no feedback. Then I was asked to provide references, which, usually signals that you are going to have an offer. My references were stellar (per the HR manager).  Several weeks later she called to say that all was fine but also announced that they had 'just hired a new Chief Development Officer' who wanted to meet with me. I had not choice but to meet with him. His experience did not really match the CDO position he had just been hired for.  He could not answer any of my questions, but that did not stop him from being arrogant.  He never thanked me for meeting with him and I never heard from him again. The HR manager called me to ask me if I had any questions--they had made the decision of putting the position on hold but did not bother telling me.  Three months passed and I received an automatic e-mail saying that they had hired someone. 

My impression, is that this is a chaotic, disorganized organization. It is characterized by big leadership gaps and bad internal communication. It is staffed b with young idealistic but naive and inexperienced employees. PIH was Boston's pet charity for a while, received lots of money during the Haiti earthquake but could not sustain the flow. If  you want to dream big, hope you can jump without a parachute without hurting yourself and earn a low salary, this is the place for you.  I am personally grateful that I did not join!
Interview Questions: The most difficult question was that they did not know what they wanted.

title: Finance Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 7 months. I interviewed at Partners in Health (Boston, MA) in Nov 2011
Interview Descriptions:
Recruited, called in, meet with almost the whole staff. Lots of goofy questions and back and forth
 Months to get to offer. Ridiculous
Interview Questions: Use your imagination and tell us a story of what you will solve in terms of global health equity...its a finance/accounting position, folks.

title: Production Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Partners in Health (Boston, MA) in Nov 2011
Interview Descriptions:
I originally applied in late October 2011 via the company website. I had previously applied for more administrative positions and had not received any sort of communication either way. I received an email from an HR staff in early November, which arranged a phone interview for mid-November. The HR staff member was late in making their phone call, but it focused on the nature of the position and the department (Training), as well as my interests, experience, and skills. A week later I went to the office for an in-person interview. I met with the majority of the department at one time. The interview was very disorganized. Members of the team entered the room at random, and many questions and discussions were repeated. The interview lasted for about an hour and a half because of constant interruptions. I was not provided with any business cards, even when I asked. Following the interview, I emailed a thank-you note to my HR contact and ask that it be extended to the rest of the team. I received no response. Between the end of November and the beginning of January, I received only one email from the HR contact, even after repeated emails and phone calls inquiring about the status of the position and interview process. Ultimately, I did not hear from the HR contact before receiving an offer elsewhere.

The team members I spoke to seem very passionate, intelligent, busy, and hard-working. However, there is also a high amount of disorganization within and between teams. Many parts of this process were last-minute, late, or completely forgotten about. It is unfortunate because this organization does really valuable work abroad.
Interview Questions: What would you contribute better to this role and team than any other candidate?

title: Production Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Partners in Health in Nov 2011
Interview Descriptions: This consisted of a phone interview with an HR person and then an in-person interview with the production team (3 people at the time). The team and the HR person all seemed very excited about the prospect of hiring me. After the interview, I never heard anything from the HR person, even after repeatedly emailing (phone number was not provided). Interview questions were about prioritizing tasks, organizational skills/experience.
Interview Questions: How would you prioritize the following tasks (I don't remember the tasks)?
